transcript:
Patient: The agenda sounds good to me. I think it covers the main things I've been struggling with lately.

Therapist: Great, let's start by reviewing your thought records and Positive Data Log from the past week. Can you share some examples of the thoughts you've been working on challenging and the evidence you've gathered to support your new belief?

Patient: Sure. One thought that kept coming up was "I'll never be able to find a new job that pays enough to cover my expenses." I tried to challenge it by reminding myself that I've been able to find jobs in the past and that I have skills and qualifications that make me a good candidate. For the Positive Data Log, I wrote down a few things, like getting a good grade on a recent assignment and having a nice conversation with a classmate.

Therapist: Those are great examples, Alex. Challenging negative thoughts about your job prospects and recognizing your skills and qualifications is an important step in building self-confidence. And noting positive experiences, like doing well on an assignment and connecting with a classmate, helps to reinforce your new belief that you are worthy of love and happiness, even when things are tough. Did you encounter any challenges while practicing these techniques?

Patient: It was hard to remember to do the thought records and Positive Data Log consistently, especially when I was feeling really down. Sometimes I didn't feel like I had the energy to challenge my thoughts or think of positive things.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, and it's okay to struggle with consistency sometimes. When you're
